stimulusHtml: Which of the following developments could best be used as evidence to support the claim in the source that “confrontational politics” led to the end of slavery in Brazil?

features.html:
“The abolitionist movement in Brazil was a struggle between classes within one nation.... 

Government leaders [in Brazil] thought that they had resolved the emancipation issue with [a law passed in 1871].... 

Although slave owners proclaimed their emancipationist sentiments...the radical abolitionists challenged these assertions [beginning in 1885].... The immediate abolitionist leaders held that [decrees that gradually emancipated enslaved people] were having little effect on the institution.

It was this move toward confrontational politics on the part of the abolitionists in the post-1885 period that finally saw the dismantling of slavery.... The army and the local police now refused to return fugitives, and mass exodus from plantations was becoming common in the most advanced plantation counties of [the capital city of] São Paulo.... When even members of the imperial family [ruling Brazil] were converted to a radical abolitionist position, there was little hope left for the slave owners. In May 1888, the government finally decreed immediate and totally uncompensated emancipation for all slaves. Thus ended the largest remaining slave regime in America, and with its destruction, African slavery was finally brought to an end in all the Americas.”

Source: Herbert S. Klein and Francisco Vidal Luna, historians, Slavery in Brazil, 2010

choicesHtml: The emancipation law of 1871 required formerly enslaved Brazilians to serve as apprentices for their former enslavers for twenty-one years.
In the year before Brazil declared the immediate end of slavery, some radical abolitionists distributed firearms to enslaved people.
Brazilian enslavers slowed the movement for abolition by claiming that slavery was a temporary economic necessity.
Members of the Brazilian imperial family had been convinced to support the abolition movement within the country.
